possible borrowing from Turkana "And the verb sár- is functionally quite similar to the Turkana auxiliary -rok- which Dimmendaal calls the “auxiliary of unexpected state of affairs” in the affirmative (1983:138) and the “unexpected negative perfective” in the negative (1983:457)." Maybe this is a contact influnce because Turkana is spoken almost in the same place

waruu-l = still-THEN; "The nominal waruul 'still', indicates the persistence of a state or the continuation of a series of actions (examples (5.94), (5.95)). It also occurs as part of the apparently derived verb wanuulwa-L 'to continue to be unable to do' (5.96)."; see also adverb parilha (and the lexical verb parilha 'keep on doing/trying')
